acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 48 hours LC50=0.14mg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (EHC78, 2001).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rabbit LD50 (dermal route) values of >2,000mg/kg and >5,010mg/kg (IUCLID (2000).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Because the rat LC50 (inhalation of vapour) values of 0.07mg/L (4 hours) (IUCLID (2000)) and 0.081mg/L (4 hours) (IUCLID (2000)) exceeded 90% of the saturated vapour concentration of 9.9*10^(-6)ppm under a saturated vapour pressure of 7.5*10^(-9)mmHg (extrapolation) [equivalent to 1.0*10^(-6)Pa (extrapolation)] (SRC (2006)), the substance was considered as "mist exposure" and was classified as Category 2.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is a solid according to the GHS criteria and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 594mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 500mg/kg, 1,400mg/kg, 1,750mg/kg, 650mg/kg and 267mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Group 3 by IARC (1991).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although acute toxicity is Category 1 and bio-accumulation is low (log Kow=1.23(PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), since there was no rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 0%(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), it was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances with melting point of >55degC are not available.

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as flammable according to ICSC (2004). Assigned to Division 6.1 (UN#2771 Thiocarbamate Pesticide (solid, toxic) (ICSC (2004))) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on positive data in multi-generation mutagenicity tests (dominant lethal tests), germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (chromosome aberration tests) and in vivo somatic cell mutagenicity tests (micronucleus tests), described in NTP DB (Access on July 2006), EHC 78 (1988) and IARC 53 (1991).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine or chlorine

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Assigned to Division 6.1 (UN#2771 Thiocarbamate Pesticide (solid, toxic) (ICSC (2004))) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the evidence of visceral anomalies in the pups at doses producing parental toxicity in rat teratogenicity studies, described in IARC 53 (1991).

self_heating_substances.rationale: Assigned to Division 6.1 (UN#2771 Thiocarbamate Pesticide (solid, toxic) (ICSC (2004))) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on test data from rabbit eye irritation studies (IUCLID (2000)): "Moderate to severe irritation." The substance is thus considered a "strong (though reversible) irritant" to the eye.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on test data from rat skin irritation studies (exposure duration unknown) (IUCLID (2000)): "Mild irritation."

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (liver),
Category 2 (blood system, adrenal gland, nervous system, kidney, muscle, urinary bladder)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement:
Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (liver)
May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (blood system, adrenal gland, nervous system, kidney, muscle, urinary bladder)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "may adversely affect the central nervous system" (IPCS (J) (2000)). Also based on the evidence from animal studies including "decreases in RBC, PCV and hemoglobin, and an increase in reticulocyte count," "centrilobular fibrocytes were seen" (JMPR Ziram (Pesticide residues in food 1996 evaluations Part II Toxicological)), "adrenal cortical hypertrophy/degeneration/vacuolation increased; there was an increase in sciatic nerve axonal degeneration and lipofuscin in tubular kidney epithelium; increased adipose replacement and narrowing of peripheral muscle fiber bundles occurred in skeletal muscle; bile duct hyperplasia and pigmented sinusoidal cell incidence increased," "urinary bladder epithelial hyperplasia was increased" (HSDB 2003). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1 (liver) and Category 2 (blood system, adrenal, nervous system, kidneys, muscles, bladder).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (systemic toxicity),
Category 2 (nervous system),
Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement:
Causes damage to organs (systemic toxicity)
May cause damage to organs (nervous system)
May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "Ingestion of 0.5L of a solution of ziram of unknown concentration was fatal within a few hours; nonspecific pathology was observed" (IARC 53 (1991)), "findings included focal necrosis of the mucosa of the small intestine, congestion and microscopic edema of many organs, diapedetic hemorrhages, focal atelectases, acute emphysema, and desquamation of alveolar and bronchial epithelium. The pathology was nonspecific" (HSDB (2003)), and "irritating to the respiratory tract" (ICSC (J) (2000)). Also based on the evidence from animal studies including "somnolency, and changes in physical capabilities" (IUCRID (2000)).
